text: well I graduated in late 2015 and have been out of the community since, so some of what I was saying might be obsolete.  Interop with root trees definitely seems like the most important thing, but yeah, hopefully Julia will just have a fresh implementation that works.  Otherwise, it really depends... just thinking back to my work in the experimental community, I was doing some stuff for a proposed new detector at RHIC and in that context I can imagine having just mostly done without root if I wanted to (though trees would have been crucial).  GEANT was probably the more irreplaceable thing, but as far as I know it should have been relatively straightforward to just compile and wrap in Julia.  During my couple of semesters with CMS, analyses tended to involve code from an existing C++ code base, and it would likely have been necessary to at least be able to link most of it, it's a little harder for me to imagine how exactly that would have worked out (also my memory is hazy).  It's a little weird for me just to imagine doing plotting in HEP without ROOT, but obviously that doesn't mean you can't do it, and maybe this is a bit of an antiquated notion anyway

text:
I agree, the data access is a big problem. Plotting, statistical data analysis, handling large data volumes, however, are problems that other sciences are tackling, too. The RooStats toolkit has some nice features, I'd like to see some of that ported at some point.
And yeah, if you want interoperability with the large C++ frameworks, that's a different beast altogether, but that's not really a ROOT problem per se. You'd have to interface the event data model to get a Julia representation in memory. Not all of the frameworks depend on ROOT.
